text: oh hi everyone totally trash tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new
brockhampton album
a road runner new light new machine this
i believe is the sixth
full-length commercial record from the
boy band
known as brockhampton this is a new lp
that i
think marks the start of a new era
having made it through a few dicey album
cycles post
the dramatic departure of former member
amir van
the group began to turn the heat back up
last year with a series of singles
labeled as being in this technical
difficulty series
it wouldn't be until this year though
that the group would come through with
the first
taste of this new album a banger
of a single buzz cut featuring danny
brown which features a raging
siren laced beat a bold verse on the
front end from kevin abstract that has
some
subtle andre 3000-esque qualities to it
not only does this track sound like the
boys are back but
it also feels like i'm listening to the
loud boisterous colorful sounds of
iridescence but
but now fully realized plus for a while
now i felt that bigger features are
something the group
should be more open to and danny brown
gave them
an incredible one hard as hell bars the
the alphas
in cells bar also that bar about uh
doxing you with crips plus i love the
dark r
b inspired outro on the track which
sounds like the start of some kind of
dark religious experience
buzz cut is the strong start to a record
that just refuses to be pinned down
because up until this point every
brockhampton lp
i think has had a pretty consistent
sound in mood
and aesthetic especially the
particularly sober ginger
but man is roadrunner all over the place
emotionally and
also in terms of the influences it
displays it's
also a record that wrestles with the
state of the world
one's past spirituality there is quite
an instrumental shift on the following
track chain on
which some hardcore fans may remember as
being a part of that technical
difficulties
single series but the new version of the
track here is just
so different and refreshing i wouldn't
be surprised if some people don't make
the connection
the warm bass skipping beats and vintage
synths
on the instrumental feel like something
straight out of the alchemist's vault
the beat as well as the hook make for a
low-key ear worm that is contrasted
nicely by some
bold expressive quotable packed verses
from dom and jpeg mafia fifth string
young peggy ringo
slick with the ink these melodies need
duolingo
same size as dualipa i love the duolingo
duallipa
a little match there where the [ __ ] my
pen go
second fiddle to weirdos you feel like
eddie winslow
meanwhile the more socially conscious
edge of dom's rapping hits pretty hard
that
marvin gaye what's going online is
fantastic following this
count on me we heard previously as a
single and i did love it as a single but
it's funny in context of the record
it does feel to me like one of the
weaker songs here
mostly because the whistle laced beat is
a little bland
on top of that vocally and lyrically on
the back end matt champion doesn't
seem to be as much of a factor as he
should be and as much as i do like the
features on the track the sweet melodic
group chorus is really the best thing it
has going for it the track bankroll is
both moody
and materialistic though narratively it
doesn't really
make a strong connection between those
two things it just merely places them
together with some sad synthesizers
flashy lyricism from asap
ferg and merlin at the very least though
it is catchy and colorful asap ferg has
not sounded this invigorated since last
decade
then the following the light seems to
have caught the attention of many fans
because of how
intensely tragic the verses from joba
and kevin on it are
features one of the better beats here
too with buzzing guitar leads sinister
organs
some captivating chord changes joba's
verse is
a very difficult listen it is incredibly
confessional dealing very directly in
his father's suicide
the details are pretty devastating
meanwhile kevin spits about the struggle
to build up his career
while also living his truth as a gay man
dealing with the bigotry that comes
with being open about that not just from
society but also his own family the
track windows runs like a dramatic piece
of gangsta rap with its
mysterious synths and head nodding beat
as well as the vicious introverse from
sogon so flexy
this is also the longest track on the lp
at six minutes and change so
every key member of the group does get
quite a bit of mic time whether you're
talking matt
dom joba kevin merlin there's even a
little beat switch on the back end that
gives us a
dreamy hip hop outro with bare face it's
like the electrifying chemistry of the
saturation era but
we're seeing the the group kind of
reflecting energy that i think is born
out of the darker world that we're all
in the midst of at the moment the
following couple of tracks on the record
see the band embracing their boy band
roots which i think in theory is good
but the results are actually a little
mixed i'll take you on featuring charlie
wilson bring some peppy beats as well as
gentle sweet vocal harmonies it's chill
and
endearing but also kind of danceable in
a way it reminds me vibe-wise of that
ghost town dj's song
my boo at night i dream of you
i like the style i like the tune but
there is
a lot of vocal processing on the singing
to the point where
every vocal feels so uniform and
kind of stiff the only voice that pops
on the entire thing
is charlie's on the very back end
meanwhile the track old news does
feature a bouncier more colorful beat
as well as bolder rap verses but then
there is the chorus which is even
more auto-tuned and hits with some
lyrics that i think could have used a
rewrite
from this point we move into a pretty
strong second half for the lp
starting with what's the occasion
another song with a
prominent guitar passage a somewhat glam
rock inspired outro
and a heart-wrenching hook sung by joba
that i just have to point out because
going into this lp i just did not
anticipate for him to
be the emotional foundry for this album
on numerous songs here
the emotions are contrasted pretty
strongly on the following track when i
ball which
instrumentally feels like a classic
piece of funky 70s soul along with the
flows that dom brings on the front end
of this track
it reads like a piece of classic kanye
like some college dropout era kanye the
song
serves as a generally uplifting moment
on the record
talking about i guess accepting things
you can't change and hoping for better
days tomorrow
then comes one of the strongest and most
unsettling bangers of brockhampton's
career and that's don't shoot up the
party
which thematically is an odd mix of
racism paranoia but also what sounds
like
uh people violently lashing out in a
a mass shooting sort of way using the
don't shoot up the party tagline as
a metaphor or even literally in this
sense
the whole song seems to be a sad anthem
dedicated to those who
may be feeling as if they're pushed to
the edge for one reason or
another presumably given the themes of
this record so far
maybe just how dark and awful the world
is at the moment plus i do also have to
commend the way the group channels
a pretty strong kendrick lamar vibe
creatively on this track too there is
real like
charade energy to this track with how
mysterious and nocturnal the intro
is and the blasts in with this great
west coast style chorus with
wailing synth leads from here we get a
pretty and serene
little sonic oasis with dear lord that
features
just vocals a lot of harmonies as well
yeah some processing but still
the soul and sweetness of the singing
here rings through
stylistically not only is it gospel
inspired but
it's almost like i'm hearing a cross
between a frank ocean but also boney
vare as well
which i mean to make that comparison in
a good way i think it's a great track
and certainly a tone setter for what is
to come on the closer the light part 2
which
is an extension of the themes on the
light earlier on the record
also a pretty sad instrumental verse
from joba
verse from kevin both of which are
diving further into the things they
rapped about earlier on
the record which honestly especially in
the case of joba gets pretty intense
to the point where for some i could
imagine it would be difficult to listen
to but still i think this track and many
others on this project
are mark of brockhampton's growing
maturity on
this lp sure there was a kinetic energy
and electricity a lightning in a bottle
a raw
quality to the way those saturation
records sounded but that energy has to
be replaced over time by a skillfulness
by
an assuredness by a familiarity with who
you are what you're doing and what
you're trying to achieve and i think
road runner for the most part is the
sound of that
there are some tracks here that for sure
i thought were kind of underwhelming
maybe a a little on the dud side but
that doesn't change the fact that the
vast majority of the songs here i either
found to be quite enjoyable
impressive or even a little mind-blowing
it was pretty great to hear the group
branching out creatively for the
majority of this record and
sounding really good doing it i'm
feeling a light too decent eight
on this one transition have you given
this record a listen did you love it did
you hate it
what would you rate it why blah blah
blah blah blah
blah over here next to my head it's
another video that you can check out hit
that up or the link to subscribe
to the channel anthony fantano
brockhampton road runner
forever
